executive_summary: Athletic Shoe Stores have experienced stable growth over the past five years, largely propelled by factors such as an improving economic environment and increased consumer interest in sports and leisure activities. Nationwide concern over the rising obesity rates has spurred higher consciousness about health among consumers. Consequently, this trend has stirred up more demand for athletic shoes due to the surge in physical activities, requiring regular replacement of worn-out footwear.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: COVID-19 HAD A SIGNIFICANT AFFECT ON THE ATHLETIC SHOE INDUSTRY
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The onset of COVID-19 in 2020 resulted in a temporary halt for the athletic shoe industry, cutting down revenues due to the closure of non-essential businesses. Major sports event cancellations and a slump in consumer spending further weakened demand for athletic shoes and contributed to the drop in industry revenue in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Health Consciousness Helps Drive Athletic Shoe Sales
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Fueled by the increased health consciousness among Americans, there's a higher demand for athletic shoes parallel with the rise of diet alterations and exercise regimen modifications. The constant wear and tear of athletic shoes due to heavy exercise routines have stimulated the frequent purchasing cycle, boosting industry revenue.

The merging of fitness and fashion in the form of the Athleisure trend has supported substantial growth in the athletic shoes industry over the past five years. The growing acceptance of casual dressing at workplaces coupled with heightened health awareness has led to a rise in athletic shoe preferences over traditional footwear options.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Addressing External Pressure on Athletic Shoe Stores
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite industry growth, athletic shoe stores face escalating external competition from department stores offering diverse shoe options and specialty retailers. Department stores' one-stop shopping convenience and specialty stores' niche offerings pose a formidable challenge to standalone athletic shoe stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: POSITIVE TRENDS WILL BENEFIT THE INDUSTRY
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the economy continues to expand, Americans will become increasingly willing to splurge on athletic shoes. Over the five years to 2028, both per capita disposable income and consumer spending are expected to expand, equipping shoppers with more available income to spend at athletic shoe stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STORES WILL EXPAND THEIR PRODUCTS TO REMAIN RELEVANT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although demand and revenue growth are expected to grow over the next five years, revenue growth will be restricted because of increasing competition from external retailers. To encourage new shoe purchases at industry establishments, companies will increasingly focus on expanding their inventory to include shoes for additional activities, like Pilates and climbing.

Though higher disposable income will lead to more spending on quality athletic shoes, the escalated price competition from larger retailers might limit potential profit gains. By sourcing their inventory from low-cost foreign manufacturers, shoe stores can curb purchase costs thus amplifying their profits.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: FOCUSING ON CUSTOM SERVICES AND PERSONALIZATION OPTIONS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Athletic shoe stores will use advanced technology to provide customers with precise shoe sizes and styles that perfectly match their feet. This not only enhances the customer's comfort and performance but also increases customer satisfaction and loyalty. Stores will offer personalized designs and features to cater to the unique needs and tastes of customers.

industry_definition: This industry includes retailers that primarily sell athletic shoes, like running shoes, basketball shoes and sneakers. This industry also includes companies that sell shoes online. Some athletic shoe stores also retail some apparel.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Participation in sports

key_trends: Athletic shoe stores compete on quality and price to attract customers. Online shopping has increased price-based competition as consumers are easily able to compare prices between stores.
External competition has increased from department stores and other large retailers. These large retailers are able to leverage economies of scale to offer competitive prices.
Athleisure trends have run up demand for athletic shoes. Individuals are increasingly purchasing athletic apparel and shoes to wear to work, to school and to run daily errands.

External competition from department stores and large retailers has increased. Large-scale retailers like Target and Walmart pose the greatest risk to stores that specialize in retailing athletic shoes.
The top athletic shoe stores benefit from brand recognition to draw in returning customers. Large companies with brand recognition also benefit from economies of scale.

Offering a wide selection of products has contributed to Footlocker and Nike being able to capture significant market share. This variety allows companies to remain in demand even when consumer preferences shift.
Athletic shoe stores must adhere to common labor laws. However, athletic shoe stores are not subject to many industry-specific regulations.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment includes consumers under 34 years old. Although these consumers generally have more available leisure time to spend on sports and recreation, this age demographic typically has lower disposable income, which limits the amount of money they can spend at athletic shoe stores. Demand from this consumer group is sometimes realized in other consumer groups because parents often purchase athletic shoes for their children. Over the past five years, this segment has slightly expanded as a share of revenue as athleisure has become increasingly popular.

The young consumers in this demographic are particularly sensitive to changing fashion trends, and as a result, the popularity of athleisure fashion has slightly boosted this segment's share of revenue.

This segment includes consumers aged 35 to 64, which is the largest market for athletic shoe stores. Consumers in this age range are typically employed with a steady stream of income, which makes them the target market for this retail industry. This consumer segment is also generally active but has limited leisure time. Consumers in this demographic are likely to have children whom they would purchase athletic shoes for.

This segment includes consumers aged 35 to 64, which is the largest market for athletic shoe stores. Consumers in this age range are typically employed with a steady stream of income, which makes them the target market for this retail industry. This consumer segment is also generally active but has limited leisure time. Consumers in this demographic are likely to have children whom they would purchase athletic shoes for.

This segment includes consumers aged 35 to 64, which is the largest market for athletic shoe stores. Consumers in this age range are typically employed with a steady stream of income, which makes them the target market for this retail industry. This consumer segment is also generally active but has limited leisure time. Consumers in this demographic are likely to have children whom they would purchase athletic shoes for.

This segment includes consumers aged 65 and older. Most of these consumers have entered retirement and have a reduced disposable income stream, which limits their willingness and ability to splurge on brand-name industry goods. Additionally, older consumers generally have reduced demand for goods sold by this industry, as they are typically less likely to participate in athletic activities.

products_and_services.product_description: Men's athletic shoes are the largest product segment in the industry. A growing number of men are purchasing athletic shoes as fashion staples.
Athleisure trends have increased demand for women's athletic shoes. Women represent a growing share of athletic shoe sales and will continue to increase their demand.

This segment includes children's athletic shoes that can be used for running, hiking, tennis and other athletic activities. Because children in this age group grow quickly, the rate at which footwear must be replaced is higher than in other age groups. Also, the youth market is very receptive to the marketing of new and trendy footwear and, therefore, demands the latest athletic shoes.

This product segment includes athletic clothes and other accessories. Significant products in this category include men's exercise apparel, women's exercise apparel, shoe laces and polishes and sporting equipment. This products category has increased over the past five years as athletic shoe stores have increased their product offerings to compete against department

tier_1_suppliers: Athletic & Sporting Goods Manufacturing in the US
Costume & Team Uniform Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Shoe & Footwear Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: While shoes are perceived as a necessity in the United States, many of the athletic shoes retailed by this industry are discretionary and often expensive. As a result, demand for industry retailers depends on consumer disposable income levels. When per capita disposable income rises, consumers can purchase discretionary athletic shoes, driving demand for industry retailers.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the highest concentration of industry establishments in the US which is in line with the region's share of the US population. Locating near a large population expands store's potential customer base. The high percentage of establishments is also due to the favorable weather conditions within the region which makes year-round athletic activity more popular. Within the Southeast, Florida accounts for the highest concentration of establishments which is partially due to the higher-than-average amount of time spent on sports and leisure in the state.

The West is the second-largest region by industry establishments. California is the largest state by establishment within the West, with demand being supported by active lifestyles and higher-than-average disposable income. Additionally, California is the most populated state in the region, making it a strategic location for stores to operate from. The West region is known to have an active population because the natural landscape within the west offers many opportunities for hiking, biking and other outdoor athletic activities.

The Mid-Atlantic region is a popular location for athletic shoe stores because it is home to many urban hubs including New York City and Philadelphia. Consumers in this region have a higher-than-average disposable income, allowing them to spend more at athletic shoe stores. New York stands out since this metropolitan hub houses many specialty stores, including large athletic footwear stores such as Nike establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) is enforced by the US Department of Labor and established minimum wage, overtime pay, record keeping, child labor laws and other employment standards that affect full-time and part-time employees. Athletic shoe stores must adhere to and enforce these regulations to avoid any potential financial penalties or law suits.

The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) is enforced by the US Department of Justice and prohibits discrimination against people with disabilities regarding employment. This act requires that stores be accessible to customers with disabilities and that prospective employees are not discriminated against in the hiring process because of their disability.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The athletic shoe store industry is mature.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady.
The market concentration level is high.
The competition level is high and increasing.

basis_points.basis_description: Athletic shoe stores compete on quality and price to attract customers.

basis_points.basis_title: Increased price competition from online shopping
basis_points.basis_description: Online shopping has increased price-based competition as consumers are easily able to compare prices between stores.
External competition has increased from department stores and other large retailers. These large retailers are able to leverage economies of scale to offer competitive prices.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Large stores have a competitive advantage. Economies of scale allow large stores to benefit from vertical integration and generate higher returns than stores that must pay wholesale prices. Brand recognition also benefits large stores as customers are familiar with the name, encouraging repeat customers. Larger stores also attract customers since they can afford to carry a variety of brands.

Small stores compete by offering specialization. Smaller stores are generally independently owned, cater to a specific geographic market and are likely to specialize in a specific type of athletic shoes, such as running shoes. Since smaller stores are less able to compete based on price, they must offer benefits to consumers in other ways, like custom fittings, in order to stay relevant and gain market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases have decreased, but remain high
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases are the largest expense for athletic shoe stores, despite decreasing slightly over the past five years. It is typical for purchases to be the largest cost for retail industries because they must purchase inventory to sell.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Most retailers in this industry buy finished products
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Most retailers in this industry buy finished products from manufacturers and sell them in their stores, meaning an increase in the price of shoes raises purchasing costs.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Revenue volatility for athletic shoe stores is influenced by consumer confidence, shoe prices and the number of consumers participating in sports.

The coronavirus increased revenue volatility in 2020 when revenue dropped significantly. Temporary store closures contributed to the drop in demand and revenue in 2020 as consumers shifted to purchasing athletic shoes from substitute industries.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: ATHLETIC SHOE STORES ARE EXPANDING VIRTUALLY
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Athletic shoe stores are increasingly focusing on their online presence by investing in user-friendly websites and mobile apps. This allows consumers to easily browse, compare, and purchase athletic shoes.

Athletic shoe stores are increasingly offering in-store custom fitting services that leverage cutting-edge technology, such as foot scanning and analysis. These methods provide precise measurements and insights into the customer's unique foot shape, arch type, and walking and running styles to optimize footwear recommendations.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market, or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: The text does not provide enough information to determine if companies in this industry specialize or offer a diversified range of products.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Since athletic footwear is a discretionary good, sales are heavily dependent on disposable income and consumer preferences.

FAQs.question: Do you contract directly with manufacturers in order to reduce purchase costs?
FAQs.answer: Large companies benefit from vertical integration and manufacturing their products in-house.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Companies retain employees through basic benefits, like employee discounts and health insurance.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Companies are reliant on workers because much of industry revenue comes from sales made in bricks-and-mortar stores. As a result, employee-to-consumer contact is particularly important.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to keep the most popular products in stock?
FAQs.answer: Companies use point-of-sale systems that keep track of product segmentation, gross margin by product, promotional activity and customer loyalty.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations?
FAQs.answer: Companies must stay up-to-date on minimum wage legislation, which varies state by state.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Companies work with industry associations, like The National Retail Federation and the American Apparel and Footwear Association, to stay up-to-date with consumer preferences.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Companies typically do not offer any payment plans because many industry products are sold on the spot and are affordable. As a result, consumers usually pay on the spot.

FAQs.question: How often does your company purchase new equipment?
FAQs.answer: Companies do not purchase capital often because the industry is very labor-intensive. However, companies are constantly purchasing new footwear products to stay up-to-date with the latest consumer trends.

FAQs.question: What brand names have you had success with in the past? What brands are most popular among consumers?
FAQs.answer: Recognized brand names can attract a higher profit margin.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in footwear? How do you ensure that you have the most popular brands in stock?
FAQs.answer: Ensuring that shoes featuring the newest technologies and fashion styles are kept in stock helps generate sales to targeted customers.

FAQs.question: How can you improve your company to receive better recommendations from companies you work with? How can you bolster your supplier relationships?
FAQs.answer: Companies that are vertically integrated or have links with suppliers can purchase goods at more favorable prices, improving profit.

FAQs.question: How does a boost in the price of shoes impact your profit?
FAQs.answer: When the price of shoes increases, retailers can either absorb the cost, which harms profit, or pass on the boost to consumers, which may lower demand.

FAQs.question: How can your company encourage participation in sports? How do you market your products to athletes?
FAQs.answer: The majority of sporting activities require athletic shoes for appropriate safety measures and comfort.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income? Are you prepared to raise production levels?
FAQs.answer: While shoes are perceived as a necessity in the United States, many of the athletic shoes retailed by this industry are discretionary and often expensive.
